title: Why these mages?

embed.description: Hey all, The next class update will be focused on “traditional” Mages and I’m here to give you guys and gals some of the initial details. Similar to the Juggernaut and Marksman releases, these updates aim to take look at an entire class of champions and accomplish 2 primary goals:

body:
Riot recently announced that the mages they will be focusing on in the mage update will be Malzahar, Vel’Koz, Brand, Vladimir, Cassiopeia, and Zyra. While it's nice to finally see who they will be changing, some of these choices are confusing to me. In my opinion, only Cassiopeia and Zyra are the two champs here that are in dire need of some changes. The rest, especially Vel'Koz, feel less in need of changes than some other immobile mages that are not on the list, such as Galio, Swain, or maybe even Annie. 

I don't think that, for the most part, they picked the right champions. Choosing Vel'Koz of all mages to change just mystifies me, especially with all the people asking specifically for him not to be changed. There are other mages struggling and I'm wondering if I can get any insight as to why they picked these 4.

replies.body:
Statikk and the other folks working on the mage update will be talking in detail about why these particular champs. At a high level our goal with these class updates is to increase distinction between characters. With the mage update especially we're also looking at some champions that are distinct, but when functional aren't healthy for the game or are in an ok spot already but have a fair bit of untapped potential for differentiation. 

 
**Ought to bring more distinct things to a team:**

* Vel'Koz - Really distinct to play as, cohesive, feels fair to play against. Doesn't bring enough distinct to a team though, so lacks a clear strategic niche or specialized tool offered. Goal with him will be to offer clearer situations where he's the right pick when you want AP poke.

* Brand - Pretty similar to Vel'Koz overall, in that he lacks a clear enough niche, so primary gameplay argument for picking him is when he's the most damaging AOE mage. Needs a somewhat more distinct toolkit basically. 


 
**Distinct, but have significant game health challenges:**

* Vlad - Does distinct things, but can be really unhealthy. Work on Vlad's going to involve a lot of 'how do we preserve the core of what he does while adding ways to play against him'.

* Malz - More game health issues than anything else. Counterplay's not great in particular, with Malz needing to just click on you and kill you given his squishiness, immobility, lack of reach, vulnerability to item system counters. Has a lot of distinctive stuff going on though. 


 
**Untapped potential/Confused identities:**

* Cass - Confused identity, unclear niche (sustained damage almost marksmen like pattern, versus poison spreading potential, versus stacking power, versus counter initiator etc). Work on Cass will need to start with constructing a clear picture of what her concept should be (suspect that'll include stripping out the stacking gameplay, though that's a guess). 

* Zyra - Does reasonably distinctive things, but has the potential for quite a bit more. Also ends up either a strong bully or struggling to function a bit too often.


Finally, as with the marksman update in preseason, we'll also be making some small tweaks to a number of other mages at the same time as these bigger changes (things like the Q reset on Twitch for example).

Why did you leave out the long range mages: {{champion:99}} {{champion:101}} {{champion:115}}  ?

They all have similar abilities and don't really have distinct niches. Especially Lux and Xerath who are both long range, combo, burst mages. Ziggs is more siege focused and less combo-burst, but it doesn't really feel like a very clear niche.

We decided we'd be best off focusing on a couple of sub types of mage here, which are basically sustained damage mages and pick mages. Artillery mages (Xerath, Ziggs etc with really long range) and supportive mages (Ori, Karma etc) are groups we might tackle later, though it wouldn't surprise me if there was more value in tackling a different group instead (assassins or some types of tank instead). 

As far as Lux/Xerath/Ziggs go I do think there's a bit more overlap there than's preferable, particularly between Lux/Xerath on pick/burst a dude and Xerath/Ziggs on clear waves/poke champs repeatedly. Lux does bring a more supportive kit than the others though, Ziggs gets more area control/mobility but gives up reliability against champions, and Xerath's got phenomenal backline access. As a result there's an ok current state distinctiveness wise. Potentially means they might just need smaller adjustments, rather than larger scale work, to pry them apart a bit.

Pardon my bluntness but Wouldn't Vel'koz count more as an artillery mage?

I'm worried that the first champ I ever got mastery 5 on and my main is getting changed for no particular reason when there are other mages who could use tweaking much more.
Yeah, Vel'Koz has a lot of artillery to him. We decided to include him here though given he's got a lot of sustained damage traits as well.

What exactally are your supposed problems with Vel'Koz? He's probably your most balanced champion on release that I can think of, has had next-to-no changes, and offers a unique playstyle as it is with his passive, Q makes you think on how to fire it, W lineup for extra damage, E has a lengthy cooldown so it's to make the player think when the right time to use it is, and his R feels oh so satsifying when used. So I must ask, what issues are there to be had with our favourite void-researcher?

Some discussion from last month that covers Vel'Koz's state:

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/5dJN5vf7-meddler-velkoz-thoughts

TLDR: Healthy, fun to play, distinct to play as, fair to play against, needs to have a more distinct reason to be brought to a team than he currently has .

If he is:
-fun to play with and against
-distinct to play as
-fair to play against
-healthy
THEN DON'T CHANGE HIM!
inb4 fiora sized update
None of these updates will be close to Fiora sized (think roughly same scale on average as the marksmen changes).

You're purposely missing the entire point of all of this:  Vel'Koz doesn't need _anything_, nor do we _want_ anything to happen to him.  

You can insist that the changes will be small and that they're hardly noticeable, but answer me honestly; how do you seriously expect us to trust you, and why are you so dead set on seeing this update through even though Vel'Koz is arguably the healthiest and most balanced champion to ever come out of Riot's doors with multiple pressing matters that should be attended to before even the thought of changing Vel'Koz should occur?

We understand there are a number of people that don't want changes to Vel'Koz and as discussed think there's a lot about Vel'Koz that's already really good. Not disputing or ignoring that sentiment. We believe though that every champion needs to bring a distinct purpose to the their team and that Vel'Koz doesn't deliver well in that regard. That makes him a great candidate for some work - good generally, but with a specific problem area that brings him down overall.

In terms of scope the changes to most of these changes are unlikely to be large, do expect them to be bigger than 'hardly noticeable' though.

By that logic, why pick Talon when you can pick Zed? Why pick Xerath when you can pick Lux? Why pick Akali when you can pick Kat/Diana? Why pick Kha when you can pick Rengar? Why pick Amumu when you can pick Nautilus? Why pick Leona when you can pick Ali? I could go on for ages with multiple examples for each champ.

That kind of logic is EXTREMELY dangerous to use. There are zero champions that don't share some overlap with other champions. Here is the logic you need to be considering instead. If something is not broken by any stretch of the imagination, then why focus resources on trying to fix something that doesn't need repair? 

To compare situations, lets say you have an older model of a car. It runs perfectly, the engine is in great condition, but the paint has a very small scratch on it. Would it make sense to replace the engine? Another example, I get a small cut on my head but I am worried about infection. So I go to the doctor and they think its a good idea to amputate my leg while treating my cut. Was the amputation necessary?

Basically, this word they are using, "distinction", has no value when it comes to gameplay. The only value it holds is when you are looking at a champions popularity. To rework a champion purely based on that is the epitome of insanity. Look at Xerath. They reworked him completely based of popularity, he was overly strong for a short while, but now that he is balanced, he is even LESS POPULAR than before the rework. So all that work they did was literally pointless in the long run.

It comes down to this, not every champion has to be a "special snowflake" to be a well designed and balanced champ.

> To compare situations, lets say you have an older model of a car. It runs perfectly, the engine is in great condition, but the paint has a very small scratch on it. Would it make sense to replace the engine? 

This honestly makes little sense because the comparison is so far removed from this discussion; the differences between champions is more like the difference between the kind of _vehicle_ you drive, or at least it's supposed to be. With these examples, whether you pick Vel'Koz over Xerath, Ziggs, Lux or champions within that vein of long range poke machines with strong waveclear is more along the lines of a question about car models. 

The question in that regard is more like whether you pick one model of the same car brand over another, such as the same kind of Humvee, where as what the plan is with these reworks is to make these champions different kinds of cars, so instead of picking just another kind of Humvee, you're picking another brand of car that does what a Humvee does, but has its own reasons for driving. In the grander scheme of things champion classes would be entire vehicle types with this kind of perspective; do you like playing tanks/driving trucks or playing assassins/driving motorcycles, that kinda deal.

Let's look at the adc reworks that came in, in particular, Graves. Graves before was basically considered a worse Lucian, and if the opposite was true Lucian was effectively the worse version of Graves, because their inherent playstyle was so similar in a role that is very specific in itself. Graves's rework changed him to be much more distinct and occupy his own niche, and is now way different from Lucian even though he occupies the same gameplay space: adc. Going back to the car analogy, it's more like before, Lucian and Graves were makes of the same brand of car, but now they're two different car brands that do specific things better than the other, while still at their core being the same kind of thing.

In Vel'Koz's case the aim is to make him more distinct within the bounds of his own gameplay niche; long range poke machine with great wave clear. Right now the class of champions he's in, which includes champions like Ziggs, Xerath and Lux, is more like a car brand as opposed to each champion being its own brand of car. They're all the same kind of BMW, where as Riot's aim is to maybe have one of them be the BMW, while another is the Hyundai and another is the Honda. They're all still effectively the same kinda thing; a champion with a specific function, but with this line of thinking they go from all being effectively the same champion with slight differences between them, to similar champions that while encompassing the same role, offer something themselves that determines why you'd pick them over the others other than the fact they're just mathematically better, which is a curse some champions have suffered from in the past and continue to suffer from. 

> Basically, this word they are using, "distinction", has no value when it comes to gameplay. 

It kinda does because if that distinction didn't exist this near 130 champion roster would effectively play like a 20 champion roster. There are distinct reasons why people pick certain tanks over others from a gameplay standpoint; more reliable engage, more raw tankiness, more crowd control, more inherent damage, synergy with certain stats, etc. There are distinct reasons why people pick certain marksmen from a gameplay standpoint, range, damage output, mobility, safety, etc. Champions being distinct from one another means they offer these things in different ways and overlap can exist, but each will shine in its own way in the end. That's what the whole mage update is about, it's not to destroy champion identities or increase champion popularity or whatever, it's all about making each champion in itself a fun and unique experience to play as and against, such that anyone who plays this game can find something to have fun with, while at the same time allowing each champion to have its own unique role that it can do in its own way even if it overlaps with others.

I think I ended up going way to far with this car analogy, but either way the tl;dr is this: Vel'Koz is fun, he's fair, he's cool. But he's so similar to champions who fill his role that he competes with them for room in the roster from a gameplay angle. Riot wants to give him, and other immobile mages, and other champions in general more breathing room in regards to that.
